description.narrative: Community health workers and other community actors have improved capacity to ensure adoption of essential family practices and timely use of curative care by mothers, caregivers, families and communities in intervention areas., which contributes to Child Health, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Evaluation And Research, Maternal And Newborn Health. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Women and children, including the marginalized and those living in humanitarian situations, have access to and use high-impact health and HIV interventions from pregnancy to adolescence.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Community health workers and other community actors have improved capacity to ensure adoption of essential family practices and timely use of curative care by mothers, caregivers, families and communities in intervention areas.

description.narrative: During 2019, aiming at scale-up of the intervention, 1970 new community health workers were trained on the complete IMCI package. The cumulative number of functional HW increased from 5,252 (end of 2018) to 7,171 in 2019. The number of districts covered with community IMCI increased from 28 in 2018 to 43 in 2019 out of the 72 health districts of the country. To improve the care of newborns at the community level, community health workers in 4 pilot districts were trained to cover monitoring, prevention and promotion of the PSBI programme for pregnant women and newborns. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:26/12/2019
